repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Innovations in Basic Education
            Project, the Second and Third NortheastBasic Education
            Projects, and the School Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the FUNDESCOLA project is
            rated satisfactory. The outcomes of the Innovations in Basic
            Education and Northeast Basic Education (NEBE) projects are
            rated moderately satisfactory. The projects exceeded or
            surpassed most targets for physical inputs and training but
            it is not clear that the learning goals were met. The
            objectives of the two NEBE projects were focused towards
            central management improvements, and these had little or no
            impact on quality improvement. Due to design shortcomings,
            Bank performance for the FUNDESCOLA project, which was
            designed to target schools, was satisfactory. Borrower
            performance is rated satisfactory for all but the
            Innovations in Education project. A number of OED lessons
            are confirmed with these projects: 1) Attention should be
            paid to state, municipal, or even school management, and
            moreover, to classromm time. States and municipalities that
            are better off are more likely to take advantage of
            Bank-financed resources. The challenge is to emcourage the
            poorer ones to benefit as well. Decentralizing school
            managmeent is not a panacea: autonomy permits the poorest or
            least knowledgeable municipalities to fall behind, without
            much possibility for helping the residents. Classroom
            observations may be used as predictors of achievement: they
            can potentially provide feedback and promote improvements
            sooner than achievement tests. Students' health needs
            and problems must be addressed to optimize cognitive
            development and classroom learning.

1960913.trustfund:
TF035276-BRAZIL - EDUCATION SECTOR,TF025482-PHRD -HUMAN CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT PORTFOLIO,TF027360-SCIENCE RESEARCG AND TRAINING PROJECT,TF027370-NORTHEAST BASIC EDUCATION,TF034238-BRAZIL - TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Innovations in Basic Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is assessed as having
            reached its development objective and is rated satisfactory.
            Sustainability of the investments in school construction,
            educational materials, and computerization of the
            educational system is dependent on adequate funding from the
            Education Secretariat for maintenance and replacement, and
            teacher and staff training for the effective use of new
            materials. World Bank preparation and appraisal, though
            lengthy, were satisfactory, with the exception of inadequate
            attention to procurement-related issues. The advent of a new
            State administration in 1995 was chiefly responsible for
            raising the level of commitment and led to eventual
            satisfactory performance. General lessons learned focus on
            procurement, flexible project design, strong monitoring and
            evaluation, strong client ownership, minimizing project
            complexity, and assessing local political cycles. There are
            also lessons to be learned from several innovative
            activities undertaken by the State of Sao Paulo, which were
            supported under this project. This report offers them in
            case studies of innovations in the following areas:
            accelerated classes, teacher training, student assessment,
            school reorganization, information technology, and the
            school lunch program.

5079128.trustfund:
TF034238-BRAZIL - TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
            IN PROCUREMENT TRAINING AND REVIEW

repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Innovations in Basic Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the project is to
            improve primary school learning and retention among children
            of poor and migrant families in Greater Sao Paulo in a
            manner that could eventually be adapted to other states.
            The project will support:  (i) a new curricular approach and
            extended school day for the first two years of primary
            school through in-service teacher training, provision of new
            educational materials, more efficient school feeding
            programs, and school construction to allow primary schools
            in poor neighborhoods to operate two daytime five-hour
            shifts; (ii) expansion of low cost pre-primary education
            provided by private non-profit organizations and
            municipalities in poor neighborhoods; (iii) reform of the
            school health program to emphasize cost-effective screening,
            referral, and health education; (iv) the strengthening of
            state and municipal education authorities; and (v)
            evaluation studies and dissemination activities.
